# List of game engines


From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia



[](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_game_engines#mw-head)[](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_game_engines#p-search)


Many tools called **[game engines](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_engine)** are
 available for game designers to code a game quickly and easily without building from the ground up.

- [Infernal Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_Reality#Infernal_Engine) — Created by [Terminal
 Reality](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_Reality), provides rendering, physics, sound, AI, and metrics for game development. Used in several games such as *[Ghostbusters: The Video Game](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghostbusters:_The_Video_Game)*, *[Mushroom Men: The Spore Wars](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mushroom_Men)*, *[Bass Pro Shops: The Strike](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bass_Pro_Shops:_The_Strike)* and *[Roogoo: Twisted Towers](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Roogoo:_Twisted_Towers&action=edit&redlink=1).*
- [Torque Game Engine Advanced](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torque_Game_Engine_Advanced) —
 A next-generation 3D game engine support modern GPU hardware and [shaders](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shader_(computer_science)).
- [Torque Game Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torque_Game_Engine) — A modified version
 of a 3D computer game engine originally developed by [Dynamix](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamix) for the 2001 FPS *[Tribes 2](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tribes_2)*.
- [TOSHI](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TOSHI) — A fourth generation cross platform game engine designed by [Blue
 Tongue Entertainment](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blue_Tongue_Entertainment).
- [Traktor
 Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Traktor_Engine&action=edit&redlink=1) — A modern and cross platform game engine with focus on performance and efficient workflow by [Doctor
 Entertainment](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Entertainment&action=edit&redlink=1).
- [Truevision3D](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Truevision3D) — A 3D game engine using the [DirectX](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DirectX) API.
- [Unigine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unigine) — All-in-one 3D engine for Windows, Linux, Mac OS X, PlayStation 3, Android,
 iOS. Supports DirectX9/10/11 and OpenGL/OpenGL ES.
- [Vengeance engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vengeance_engine) — A video game engine based
 on the Unreal Engine 2/2.5
- [Vicious Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicious_Engine) — Available for Microsoft Windows, Sony PlayStation 2,
 Microsoft Xbox, and Sony PlayStation Portable
- [Virtools](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virtools) — A 3D engine combined with high-level development framework, used for
 game prototyping and rapid developments. Available for Windows, Macintosh, Xbox, PSP. Can publish standalone or for the 3DVia Web Player browser plugin.
- [Vision Engine 8](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vision_Engine_8) — A cross-platform game engine,
 developed by [Trinigy](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trinigy). Used in games such as: [Arcania:
 A Gothic Tale](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arcania:_A_Gothic_Tale), [The Settlers 7: Paths to a Kingdom](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Settlers_7:_Paths_to_a_Kingdom), [Dungeon
 Hero](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dungeon_Hero), [Cutthroat](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Cutthroat_(video_game)&action=edit&redlink=1),
 and [Three Investigators](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Investigators).
- [Visual3D.NET Game Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual3D.NET_Game_Engine) — All-in-One
 3D game engine and toolset, fully written in [C#](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_Sharp_(programming_language))/[.NET](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microsoft_.NET) for [Windows](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows) A
 browser player is roadmapped for v1.1.
- [WGAF](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WGAF) — The game engine developed by [Guild
 Software](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guild_Software) which powers their MMORPG *[Vendetta Online](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vendetta_Online)*.
- [X-Ray](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Ray_(engine)) — The game engine developed by [GSC
 Game World](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GSC_Game_World) which powers their FPS series, "[S.T.A.L.K.E.R](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S.T.A.L.K.E.R)".
- [XnGine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XnGine) — Developed by [Bethesda
 Softworks](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bethesda_Softworks), one of the first true 3D engines.
- [Zillions of Games](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zillions_of_Games) — used to develop games that happen on a grid,
 like chess

### [[edit](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_game_engines&action=edit&section=4)]Freeware

These engines are available for free use, but without the source code being available under an [open
 source license](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_source_license). Many of these engines are commercial products which have a free edition available for them:
- [BYOND](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=BYOND&action=edit&redlink=1) — A free 2D
 engine for making top-down, isometric, or side scroller games for Windows.
- [dim3](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dim3) — Freeware 3D javascript engine for the Mac (although finished games are cross platform).
- [Defold](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Defold) — Cross platform 2D game engine with built-in collaboration. Support for iOS,
 Windows, Mac OS X, Linux.
- [DX Studio](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DX_Studio) — A freeware 3D game engine with complete tools for 3D video game development.
 Upgrading to paid licenses would unlock extra features.
- [Future Pinball](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Future_Pinball) - A pinball engine.
- [Game Editor](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Editor) - A free 2D game engine capable of making games for PC, Mac, Linux,
 iOs, GP2X, Smartphone, Pocket PC, and in version 1.5, Box 2D, and Android Beta. Also uses C as a scripting system.
- [Game Maker](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_Maker) — A free game engine oriented towards beginners and people that do
 not want to learn how to program. A paid upgrade unlocks 3D Direct 3D support along with the ability to run Native Code.
- [NeoAxis
 Game Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Neoaxis_(game_engine)&action=edit&redlink=1) — Windows and Mac OS X multi-purpose 3D Engine with Web deployment. For simulation, visualization and games. Free for Non-Commercial projects.
- Polygon Movie Maker / [MikuMikuDance](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MikuMikuDance) — A proprietary freeware 3D animation
 program written by Japanese developer Yu Higuchi. Notable for including several models of [Vocaloid](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vocaloid) characters,
 but lacking any features to create new models.
- Papaya Social Game Engine - A free cross platform 2D OpenGL game engine developed by [PapayaMobile](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PapayaMobile) for
 Android and iOS.
- [Source engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source_engine) SDK — Based on the game engine developed
 by [Valve Software](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valve_Software) for *[Half-Life 2](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Half-Life_2)*.The SDK is bundled with any Source game.
- [Stencyl](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stencyl) - A Windows, Mac, and Linux development tool for 2D games. Physic support,
 if desired in the game, is provided through Box2D integration. Stencyl can publish a single project to multiple target platforms, including Flash, iOS, and Android. Certain publishing options are available via yearly subscriptions.
- [Unity](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unity_(game_engine)) — a game engine not tailored to a specific gamestyle
 for web, Windows, and Mac OS X (and soon Linux). The free version is feature limited compared to the PRO version. Support for the iPhone, Android, Nintendo Wii, PlayStation 3, and the Xbox 360 is available as addon licenses.
- [Unreal Engine 3](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unreal_Engine_3) / UDK — UE3 is still considered
 as one of the most popular game engines in the top market. Epic games released a free edition, called UDK (a binary release of the engine), which allows you to use the engine to create non-commercial games and applications for free. Commercial titles are also
 allowed under specific terms.[[11]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_game_engines#cite_note-11)
- [CryEngine 3](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CryEngine_3) SDK — CryEngine 3 is a new generation engine
 developed by Crytek to create the FPS game Crysis 2. The engine has been released recently, with a royalty bearing license model that is similar as with the UDK release of the Unreal Engine 3.
- [Visual Pinball](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Pinball) - A pinball game engine.
- [World Builder](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Builder) — A classic Mac OS game engine.
- [Wintermute Engine](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wintermute_Engine) — A runtime and development tools for creating
 2D and 2.5D point'n'click adventure games (Windows) . A "lite" Version is also available, but without the 3D Actor function (Windows, MAC, Linux)[[12]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_game_engines#cite_note-12)[[13]](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_game_engines#cite_note-13)
